title: cumbernaulds-plook-faces-demolition
story: North Lanarkshire Council is reviewing the future of Cumbernauldrsquos brutalist concrete heart as part of a pound. billion decade-long investment programme across its region.Its leader, Jim Logue, will today unveil what he calls a ldquobold sht away from shopping for the commercial and public hearts of eight towns, including Cumbernauld.He will ask councillors next week to back a vision that would also see empty and under-used shops in Airdrie, Wishaw, Motherwell, Shotts, Kilsyth, Coatbridge and Bellshill swept away to make space for new homes, schools and other community assets.Mr Loguersquos drive reverses years of piecemeal and ineffective le support for ailing town centre retail drags ndash usually through investment in urban realm.:Ayr in the running to be named Scotlands most beautul high streetA paper from his chief executive, Des Murray, sets out proposals to ldquoreposition town centres as vibrant mixed-use centres.It sets out broad themes for new ldquotown hubs that would incorporate schools, leisure and other public services to be relocated from their current peripheral sites.However, officials stress the exact shape of each new re-imagined town centre, including Cumbernauld, will be subject to further consultation, with bespoke solutions for each community.Mr Logue said for too long councils had failed to think holistically, seeing issues like the locations of schools or leisure and culture centres as separate from economic development or town centre regeneration.He said: ldquoI donrsquot think town centres can be saved in their present form.ldquoYou canrsquot bring back the old retail. That has gone. We have to think of a dferent approach to town centres and what is envisaged in the hubs is far more sustainable.ldquoWe have to have a core medium-to-long-term plan. In the past we have not had that plan.ldquoI think this vision is bold and ambitious. Do you want us to continue doing what we are doing  Becausewe do, it is tantamount to managing decline. You can see that in all the town centres in North Lanarkshire.Most of North Lanarkshirersquos town centres are privately owned and officials will have to assemble land for their plans, including with multiple small and large retail landlords.Officials are understood to be already taking to some property owners as they seek to contract the retail offering.:Carbuncle award scrapped after  years highlighting Scotlands ugliest building and most dismal town#They stress they are eager to keep iconic architecture, such as the former Orrs department store in Airdrie which is about to be turned in to council flats  years after it closed its doors.However, the concrete heart of the Cumbernauld new town ndash voted twice as Scotlandrsquos ldquoplook on the plinth or ugliest architectural feature ndash is not something they want to save.Mr Murray openly refers to ldquogetting rid of the plook of the plinth, but he also stresses he is not trying to shut shops people are using now.Asked what he would do with the site, he said: ldquoIt gets replaced with a town hub, with an advanced or dferent retail offering, with more housing of a higher standard.North Lanarkshire Council ndash like all others ndash is facing an ongoing squeeze on its revenues, one that has lasted since austerity was imposed after the  financial crash.However, the local authority, thanks to low debt and high growth, can access loans for capital investment, not least for its housing stock.So it finds itself revenue poor but, potentially, capital rich.This borrowing ndash as well as money from the City Region Deal it shares with the rest of West Central Scotland ndashwill fund investments in schools, housing and infrastructure in to what Mr Murrayrsquos report refers to as a ldquocoherent overarching framework for place-based investment.

title: budget-bosses-urge-scotland-follow-rishi-sunaks-lead
story: Chancellor Rishi Sunak announceda pound billion package to get throughthe outbreak, including a one-year suspension of business rates for many hospitality and entertainment venues.He said the poundbn tax cut would save the firms that benefited in England up to pound, in  .It prompted business leaders tocall for similar measures north of the Border by drawing on pound millionof extra funding now going toHolyrood through the Barnettfunding formula.Dr Liz Cameron, chief executive of the Scottish Chambers of Commerce, said: ldquoWe urgently need the Scottish Government to invest any extra funds into business support and boosting the economy, which faces huge challenges in the coming weeks and months.ldquoThe Scottish Chamber Networkis ready to work with the Scottish Government on how these fundsare best used to protect jobs and businesses.ldquoIn the first instance, we call on the Scottish Government to support small businesses by immediately adapting the Small Business Bonus scheme to match the Chancellorrsquos pledges of support for small companies in England.ldquoAnd to consider also suspending rates bills for retail, leisure and hospitality firms in Scotland as theUK Government has announced.rsquorsquoShe added: ldquoUnless mitigated, the effect of a coronavirus pandemicin the coming weeks ndash coupled with ongoing uncertainty in other areassuch as Brexit ndash risk heaping long-term damage to the Scottish economy, leading to further under-performance in terms of GDP growth and productivity.ldquoScotland needs investment in better transport infrastructure and swtreductions in the cost of doing business.rsquorsquoThe Federation of SmallBusinesses in Scotland welcomed the UK Government covering  days of statutory sick pay for employees off work because of the virus at companies with fewer than  employees.Scotland policy chairman Andrew McRae said good businesses should not go to the wall because of short-term cash flow problems caused by the virus.He said: ldquoMany local Scottish firms already receive important rates help from the Scottish Government.ldquoWersquoll be seeking early talks with ministers in Edinburgh to urge themto investigate what  they can do, especially for businesses in hospitality and tourism, given the moves wersquove seen [in the Budget].ldquoIf the smallest firms in England are receiving one-off grants to help see them through, then we need to see decision-makers ensure local businesses in Scotland donrsquot lose out.Scottish Finance Secretary Kate Forbes said ldquourgent claricationwas needed on exactly what funding Scotland would receive from the Budget as it confronted the coronavirus.She said cross-border ldquorapid joint engagement was needed to get through the economic shock associated with the outbreak.The public finances remainedldquovery uncertain in the short term.She said: ldquoIt is vital our businesses, employees, health service and the most economically vulnerable in our society are all protected through this time, and this additional funding will help us in our response.ldquoI will ensure businesses in Scotland are supported and will work with the business community to identy the most effective measures available tous, when we have more clarity on the funding available.ldquoWe expect full [Barnett funding formula] consequentials from this additional funding and need urgent clarication to provide clarity for Scottish businesses and NHS Scotland to ensure we can respond effectively.ldquoThe Barnett consequentials arein line with the assumptions that underpinned the Scottish Budget and Budget Bill passed by the Scottish Parliament last week. While this funding is welcome, our resource budget is still lower in real termsthan it was in  .Scottish Tory MSP Donald Cameron said the Budget was ldquoexcellent forboth Scotland and the UK, offering protection to workers and businesses.He said: ldquoItrsquos essential the Scottish Government now steps up to take similar action to ensure people in Scotland are afforded the same reassurances.ldquoThe Budget also delivered an extra poundm in Barnett consequentials for Scotland, which is in addition to the pound.bn announced last year.ldquoThis is a Conservative UK Government that invests in Scotland, and is committed to economic growth and boosting public services.ldquoIf the SNP Government was anything like as committed, peopleand businesses would be in farbetter shape.The Scottish Greens said the Budget was ldquodangerous because of its emphasis on building new roads and the continued freeze on fuel duty.Co-leader Patrick Harvie said theUK Government was putting ldquoderegulated economic growth over people and planet.He said: ldquoMuch more should have been done to protect those with insecure pay and rent from coronavirus disruption, and there were noserious proposals to tackle theclimate emergency.ldquoSplashing poundbn on major road expansions and maintaining the poundbn-a-year freeze on fuel duty that has driven up transport emissions,this is a Government unable to breakits addiction to roadbuilding or its devotion to lobbyists.ldquoThe Chancellor said he was lsquomindful of the environmentrsquo, but itrsquos clear this Government is nothing of the sort.ldquoWestminster is investing in the problem, rather than the solution, and the Scottish Government must notdo the same with the poundm extra consequentials coming to Scotland. That means ministers following the advice of their own infrastructure commission and investing in low carbon alternatives.Scottish Labour welcomed new investment in the Budget but said it only proved the previous decade of austerity had been a ldquofailed experiment.MSP Rhoda Grant said: ldquoThese measures go nowhere near to reversing the damage done to the economy and to peoplersquos livelihoods by the last years of Tory rule. Scottish Labour believes additional [Barnett Formula] consequentials must be brought forward to the Parliament to discuss the Scottish Governmentrsquos spending plans. Additional funding from this Budget must be used to deliver transformational investment in the areas that need it most, such as local government and social care.An Office of Budget Responsibilityanalysis produced alongsidethe Budget said Brexit had already depressed the UK economy by about  per cent of GDP, or poundbn.It also said the money saved on EU contributions as a result of Brexit would be pound.bn this year, or around poundm a week, far short of the poundm a week put on the side of a bus during the  referendum campaign.Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie said: ldquoWhat the Budget was missing was an honest assessment of the economic cost of Brexit, and the way in which Brexit limits the size of our economy and the amount we can invest in future prosperity.ldquoThe Office for Budget Responsibility says Brexit has frozen business investment and there are other big hits coming down the line. We would have more money to invest in boosting the economyit werenrsquot for Brexit.

title: coronavirus-we-just-days-prepare-worst
story: Scotlandrsquos Chief Medical Officer Dr Catherine Calderwood confirmed that one of the nine new cases identied in Scotland was in a patient whose infection could not be traced either to travel or contact with another known case.Evidence of community transmission was expected, but it is considered a key tipping point in the spread of the virus.It came as the World Health Organisationofficially declared coronavirus a global pandemic.Dr Calderwood said: ldquoWe have identied the first case of community transmission in Scotland, which is unrelated to contact or travel.ldquoThis was identied through our enhanced surveillance scheme. It is important to emphasise that we are still in the containment phase.ldquoThis case was to be expected and highlights the importance of the additional measures we have put in place to identy positive cases beyond self-identication.A total of  cases of coronavirus Covid- have now been confirmed in Scotland, among a UK total of  with eight dead.Across the UK the number of patients diagnosed with the virus has doubled in four days, with signs that transmission is accelerating. The most recent daily increase of  new cases is the sharpest spike to date.In Scotland, cases have been confirmed in all but four health board regions: Highland, Dumfries and Galloway, Orkney and the Western Isles. The highest number of cases ndasheight ndash has been detected in Lothian.It came as health bosses outlined plans to deploy thousands of student nurses and medical students to bolster frontline NHS resources for a surge in seriously ill patients.Scotlandrsquos Health secretary Jeane Freeman said NHS modelling indicated that the virus could result in an absence rate of between  per cent and % among health service workers.NHS staff are at ldquogreater risk of contracting the disease as a result of caring for infected patients, even with protective equipment.To help cope with staff shortages, Ms Freeman said the NHS is looking at how recently retired staff canto work, as well as how those who are almost qualied can help.Ms Freeman said there are ldquosomething like , available nursing students as well as medical students in their fth and final year of university study.She said they could play an ldquoimportant role in supporting the NHS, but would only be asked to do skills within their training.NHS England also unveiled plans to parachute up to , third-year undergraduate nurses onto the frontline as paid volunteers.Sir Simon Stevens, chief executive of NHS England, said the UK would be ldquoshortly entering a phase where we are going to be taking measures at the population level to spread the number of cases over a long period of time to lessen the impact on the NHS. He added: ldquoWe have a window of days, a few weeks, to get ourselves prepared.Ms Freeman also admitted that Scottish Government plans to increase the number of available hospital beds, including doubling Scotlandrsquos intensive care capacity, would be achieved partly by cancelling and delaying routine operations such as hip and knee replacements.NHS bosses have insisted that urgent work such as cancer surgery and chemotherapy would not be affected. Scotland has around , acute beds and  in intensive care units, but the Government has estimated that a worst-case scenario could see around , requiring critical care.Ms Freeman said: ldquoWe have active work going on looking at how we can increase the number of beds available in our hospital settings, doubling the number of intensive care units that we have and equipping them and staffing them. You start to make dficult decisions about NHS care that is critical to le ndash that would be cancer treatment, transplants, maternity care ndashfrom NHS care that is not critical to le. That is some of our elective work, the replacements of knees, hips andso on.ldquoYou start to scale down the non-critical in order to free up the space for the critical.ldquoThat is where you get additional bed space but you also can get additional intensive care space.There were also warnings that the Houses of Parliament could exacerbate the epidemic in the wake of health minister Nadine Dorriesrsquo diagnosis with Covid-. She was self-isolating at home as both her offices were sealed off and one of her staff fell ill.Glasgow MP Carol Monaghan said: ldquoOn top of the  MPs and the  peers, it is estimated that up to , people work on the parliamentary estate, with , more visiting daily.ldquoEach week we are crammed into a pungent chamber that is too small to accommodate everyone, and find ourselves up close and personal in crowded voting lobbies.ldquoAfter our week in Westminster we travel back to every part of the UK to meet local constituents and organisations. Anything we may have picked up in these confined conditions will be taken with us, and by continuing to operate Parliament in this manner, we could be creating  vectors for this virus.It comes as a petition to close schools and colleges across the UK exceeded , signatures, and Europa League clashes between Spanish and Italian sides Sevilla and Roma, and Inter Milan and Getafe, were postponed in a bid to curb infections.The Premier League also called off its first match over fears that Arsenal players ndash who were due to face Manchester City ndash might have been exposed to the virus when Nottingham Forest owner, Evangelos Marinakis, who has tested positive for the virus, visited the Emirates stadium.

title: calmac-apologises-no-suitable-vessels-can-take-arran-run
story: The vessel is now  years old and sourcing parts to repair problems that arise is a huge challenge for us. It is well documented that we were expected to have a new vessel on this route two years ago. While we were working on an original lead-time of six weeks from Europe for a replacement mooring winch for the Caledonian Isles, we now believe this will be much shorter and we can bring the vessel back into full service earlier.However, the suggestion that there are suitable vessels somewhere in the world ready to be leased or bought and take over the Arran run is unfortunately not true. There are no second-hand ferries available which meet the unusually shallow draft requirements on the West Coast, interface into our port infrastructure and which can operate in our challenging waters. We have continually searched the market along with Cmal in the last six years and brokers are fully alert to our needs. While a number of vessels have been put forward, they have either not met the demanding requirements of UK class or the work required to get them to a class level would be uneconomic or unachievable.In the meantime, I can only apologise to the Arran community for the disruptions that are taking place, pledge that we are working with all partners to ensure the ferry is fully operational as soon as possible and assure you that we engage with communities on a daily basis around the disruption that occurs.Robbie Drummond,Managing Director, CalMac Ferries Ltd, Gourock.THAT Scottish politicians and many of your correspondents letters focus on nationalism in politics is understandable, but what are our elected politicians really in office for National defence against foreign invasions of all sorts, must claim top priority of course, but the maintenance of the law and vigorous encouragement of prosperity are close in importance.Reports of so-far-unsolved problems upon which local prosperity depends, respectively in the Aviemore area and the Isle of Arran, are still, after long delays, very worrying to the locals, visitors and harmful to Scotlands tourism.Thus, the damaged Cairngorm Mountain Railway and the failing connections by ferries with Arran ought to demand almost the very highest priority in our politicians attention.Looking after the infrastructure is likewise vital, from roads, including potholes, to buildings of all kinds needing maintenance and restoration.On the European continent especially, in say, the German-speaking countries, any such knotty problems arising which hurt both tourism and the national wellbeing are, in my observation, given very high priority. Logically, their politicos support and participate in these constructive efforts, with benefits to the locals and their visitors and also to national morale.Do our own politicos see these priorities that way, not forgetting that successful resolution of such dficulties are, very justiably, potential vote-winners  Charles Wardrop, Perth.Read more: Islanders anger as safety issue brings Scotlands busiest ferry to a haltRead more:

title: letters-need-scottish-parliament-ever-just-now
story: The Westminster Parliament did not ldquochoose to pay us more. This is how the system works ndash it is the consequence of a process, rather than a ldquochoice. Of course, they could change the process now but the implications of this would be clear, for the Scottish deficit has not happened ldquoevery year. Ten years ago Scotlandrsquos deficit was less than that of the UK as a whole. We might not have been paying our way, but we were paying more of it than the UK as a whole. Nor is it a good idea to draw a conclusion based on only a few yearsrsquo data. Estimates of Scotlands fiscal position between  and  y between a surplus of pound billion and poundbn, mainly due to dferent assumptions about the rate of interest we would have earned on these surpluses.However, the important point is not just that Scotland would have had years with a very considerable surplus, but that this surplus could have been invested to provide a ldquonest egg for when things turned down. This was the strategy employed by Norway, who now have the biggest investment fund anywhere in the world, which will support them for many, many years to come. The UK in contrast chose to spend this, to reduce deficit requirements, pay for tax cuts, and continues to do so.In short Ms Stephensonrsquos use of the most current data is opportunistic, but it is less contentious than whether or not she is aware that the Scotland Office was responsible for health and education prior to devolution. The Scotland Office might not have been the direct provider, but it was the source of policy, and thinking that through is an object lesson in just why we need the Scottish Parliament more than ever just now.Imagine there were no Scottish Parliament, and policy was set and managed in the Scotland Office. While the Conservatives may have a UK majority of , in Scotland they have only six seats, while the SNP holds . However, the Secretary of State and all the ministers in the Scotland Office would all be Conservatives, implementing a series of policies resoundingly rejected by the Scottish electorate. This might be Ms Stephensonrsquos notion of democracy, but it certainly is not my own. She might do well to consider her own stricture to be acquainted ldquowith the facts, eventhey are not immediately obvious.Alasdair Galloway, Dumbarton.I APOLOGISE to Jill Stephenson for my ldquowrong answer to her question on the benefits of devolved government: the answer is Scottish democratic accountability. In the governing model she refers toof the powers of the previous Scottish Office, she asserts ldquodirect Scottish control. I disagree totally.The job of Secretary of State for Scotland was considered as one of the lowest-ranked Cabinet ministers at Westminster: their purview was policy administration, not policy formulation, and they had very little elbow room for dferentiation for Scotland from the UK. Ironically they tended to utilise Scottish ldquonationalist opinion to emphasise a need for a softer delivery of any unpopular policy.The Barnett formula was instigated just a vast sums of oil revenue was pouring into the Treasury. Even with Barnett, Scotland has paid more money per capita than it has received over the le span of the policy _ and it can be taken away at any point by Westminster.It is not easy to figure out where British nationalism is leading Scotland. Separatism in the EU centralisation in the UK a substantial infrastructure program for ldquonorthern Englandwhile in Scotland we have the ludicrous suggestion of a bridge tunnel pie in the sky in an attempt at deflection. Alister Jack may as well have a part in a Gilbert and Sullivan comic opera: he lacks purpose, direction or gravitas in his present non-job.GR Weir, Ochiltree.IF a country with more natural resources per head than any other similar nation, higher GNP and GDP than all of them and a history unsurpassed in the whole world of innovation and invention needs a big bung annually from the UK then I can think of no more pressing argument for its independence. Or, to put it another way, the -year union has obviously done monumental damage to the Scottish economy.Jill Stephensonpresenting figures to us that have been comprehensively exposed on many occasions as carefully chosen to present the Scottish economy in a suppliant position destroys instead any case for the union.The suggestion is that a UK in over pound trillion of debt, increasing daily and now arguably unsustainable, is hanging on to poor wee Scotland to subsidise it.Aye, right.David McEwan Hill, Sandbank, Argyll.BRIAN Quailpresents reasonable definitions of nationalism in his letter, but as with the majority of those with a narrow Scottish nationalist separatist agenda, falls into the nationalist xenophobic psyche when he states he does ldquonot want to be dictated to by another government. After massive financial rescue following the disastrous Darien Scheme, ldquothe people of Scotland have been democratically well represented at the best, most respected Parliament in the world with, in many cases, Scots being at the helm of it.If Mr Quail feels the Westminster Parliament is ldquoanother government, he truly has totally been taken in by the hapless, controlling regime which they call the Scottish ldquoGovernment weekly failing ldquothe people of Scotland. Of course, Mr Quail and his like want to replace the ldquoother government with another government ndash based in Brussels. There is no logic in this.Douglas Cowe, Newmachar.IF there were an election in Scotland tomorrow, we can be pretty sure the SNP would romp home again. Everyone is aware of the warped electoral system and of course that the pro-UK party voters would once again outnumber the nationalists but cancel each other out.Yet those outside looking in must wonder how a nationalist party that seems to stumble from one disaster and or scandal to the next, with eye-wateringly incompetent ministers and a leadership at war, can be so electorally successful.The answer clearly is that they are not voted in for achievement or competence or ability but on their willingness to keep a vocerous and zealous minority satisfied.How I wish we could get back to the old days when parties were elected on policies and competence.Alexander McKay, Edinburgh EH.RUTH Marrtells us how lucky we are to live in Scotland. She always mentions prescription charges and with this in mind I see that the majority of the nearly  million people living in England do not pay for this service. My council has now announced a . per cent rise in my council tax which will take care of my pension rise. How lucky am I Alan Barlow, Paisley.Read more: Scotland would not have to go it alone on defence

title: neil-mackay-loved-nicotine-now-life-go
story: Irsquom quitting cigarettes. And Irsquove bought a load of egg boxes to sound-proof my work-room at home so no-one needs to hear me scream and cry for a quick death. For the sake of my family I think Irsquoll go into self-isolation, and live out my shameful cold turkey away from the eyes of others.Right now, Irsquove just smoked my last cigarette ndash the beautul little monster. As I write this, itrsquos No Smoking Day ndash March , . My personal Ash Wednesday.Irsquove been shilly-shallying about quitting for months. I was going to stop before Christmas, but why spoil Christmas  I was going to stop as a New Yearrsquos resolution ndash but New Yearrsquos resolutions are stupid and cursed. Then I was sure Irsquod stop in February on my th birthday, as I got the shivers about my own mortality. It didnrsquot happen, though.But No Smoking Day became a mental line in the sand for me. It was now or never. I want to stay alive to seeI have grandchildren, and I still havenrsquot got around to watching the Mad Men boxset. Although that might be a bad idea as everyone smokes on that show.Irsquom genuinely scared of giving up ndash which sounds pathetic, and is pathetic, as Irsquom the one who chose to smoke. Itrsquos a hard affair to break off.Cigarettes have been with me since before I was born. My mum ndash like many mums in the sixties and seventies ndash only stopped smoking when she was pregnant with me because of morning sickness. She started smoking again after I was born. My generation imbibed tar with milk.I think no more badly of my parentsrsquo generation and their attitude to cigarettes than I do of parents today who stick iPads under their childrenrsquos noses to shut them up. At least my parents talked to me as they smoked and damaged me.I recall my childhood across a veil of cigarette smoke. I remember watching Morecambe and Wise, and Coronation Street, and Moonlighting, and I Claudius through a fug of tobacco. Everyone smoked, everywhere, all the time. My headmaster at primary school smoked in his office school staff rooms were cigarette dens. People smoked in hospitals, on planes.Of course, warnings began appearing on cigarette packets in the early s, but no-one really cared that much. My grandmother would tell me Irsquod stunt my growthI smoked, while she lit another Embassy Red. It was more the rising cost of cigarettes which troubled folk.Smoking was also dangerously, stupidly, cool. Itrsquos hard to imagine how cool cigarettes were back then. Now, cigarettes are like the mark of Cain ndash smoking singles you out as mucky and common and thick. Back when I was a kid, though, smoking made you a rebel and interesting ndash you could be your own little Jack Kerouacyou had a fag in one hand and a book in the other.So I vividly remember ldquoteaching myself to smoke. I was . I bought a packet of Players ndash as quite literally anyone could buy cigarettes then ndash and a bottle of raspberryade. My parents were out. I sat in front of the TV, watching Blue Peter, and ldquotaught myself how to inhale. Every time I choked, I reached for the raspberryade.What a bloody wee idiot. I wish I could go back in time and kick myself straight in the a**e. Nearly all my friends and girlfriends smoked. As we got older and started partying, cigarettes were as much a part of teen social rituals as music, cider and snogging.Cigarettes became embedded in my le ndash they got me through exams, followed me to nightclubs, and on holiday. I was in a steady relationship with nicotine now. By the time I left university in the early s, however, something had changed. Cigarettes were losing their glamour. They were starting to be just plain scary.My grandmother smoked from her teens into her eighties. She lived to . But when she died, not long after I graduated, doctors said she might easily have hit  or even lived longershersquod only stopped smoking much earlier. In the end, it was smoking which killed her.I quit cigarettes then. It was hard but I thought of my gran and within weeks I wasnrsquot suffering those ghastly, crippling cravings anymore. I was clean for years ndash until I moved from my home in Northern Ireland to Scotland.When I arrived here in the mid-s, I had to make new friends. I knew nobody in Scotland, so I was always out at pubs or clubs getting to know folk, building up a new network of pals. At that time, a lot of people my age were still smokingndash and I started back on the tabs. Everyone was doing it, so why shouldnrsquot I This time, I bet my gran wanted to cross over from the afterle to kick me up the a**e.That was -odd years ago. Since my children were born Irsquove hated my stupid addiction. I hated that I felt a bad role model, I hated that I might shorten my time with them.The smoking ban, and pictures of hideous diseases on tobacco packaging, have long burned away my dumb notions of glamour. If you smoke now yoursquore a pariah.Smoking is just a long game of Russian Roulette. My mum finally stopped in her seventies ndash when she was diagnosed with a severe respiratory disease.I feel really quite stupid, and quite angry at myself, for allowing this terrible lover nicotine to take such dangerous control of my le over so many long years.I want to protect myself physically now ndash not necessarily just for me, but for those I love.Irsquom going to do it. And this all makes me think, thatI can kick one bad lover out of my le, then I can kick another out too. If I beat cigarettes, social media goes next. Why protect my body,Irsquom not prepared to protect my mind, my soul Neil Mackay is Scotlandrsquos Columnist of the Year

title: jeremy-peat-sunak-delivers-remarkably-positive-budget-difficult-time-country
story: First, the Bank of England had cut interest rates by one half of one per cent and enhanced the banking systemrsquos ability to introduce other measures to assist iniduals and businesses struggling as the impact of Covid- intensied.Second, this will not be the only Budget statement this year. We can expect both a full statement on the public expenditure plans and another Budget per se, as the year progresses. Some procrastination on other topics was excusable.Despite the inevitable focus on mitigating the effects of the virus it is still essential to ask questions about the macro and the micro implications of this Budget. The macro relates to the overall state of the economy, past and projected, along with the budgetary ldquostance. The micro considers more the inidual measures announced, including changes in taxation or patterns of expenditure. How do these relate to the needs of the economy and stated Government objectives For plausibility it was essential for this Budget to include measures to help achieve the Governmentrsquos target on reducing CO emissions and to counter the growing menace of flooding.Consider first the actions related the adverse effects of the coronavirus. Here action was necessary to shore up theimpacts on both the supply and demand sides of our economy ndash in addition, of course, to resource availability for the NHS.Inevitably the Government deficit will rise in the coming year. However, Mr Sunak still committed to staying within the fiscal rules included in the last manesto. He confirmed that the Office for Budget Responsibilitywas forecasting a current account surplus in each of the next five years and an overall level of Government debt lower at the end of the Parliament than now albeit with the overall Government deficit rising for a period before it fell back.The OBR forecasts for GDP growth were made before the virus risks materialised, and they are still very disappointing. Growth was expected to be very weak this year, then to accelerate a touch in , before averaging just .% in the following three years ndash with the OBR forecast for productivity growth revised down again.This is where the Government hopes for a major positive impact from their massive commitment on infrastructure spend. It had been pre-announced that the Treasury would increase funding for infrastructure projects to the highest level in real terms since  ndash more than poundbn over the five-year term.This was a massive positive for the Chancellor to throw into the mix and includes major increases in funding for RD investment plus substantial new streams of funding for broadband, railways and roads. The expenditure, we are told, is to be well distributed geographically. It was suggested that the OBR believes this major boost to investment could result in productivity being .% higher than now at the end of the Parliament. We shall see.There were also more funds for flood protection and climate change mitigation measures ndash forests and peat bogs, red diesel subsidies abolished for most sectorsand more charging points for electric vehicles. More detail will come in the fullness of time.Inevitably emphasis was on the short-term risks of the coronavirus. We must welcome the efforts to shore up supply and demand, and hope the impact proves to be relatively short-term. It is good news that this year the fiscal stance has been eased markedly, alongside that cut in interest rates.This was very much needed. But fiscal credibility and sustainability are also critical and hence the retention of the fiscal framework, at least until a review is completed in the autumn, is another positive.There will be a substantial feed-through of funds to Scotland via the Barnett formula, with more big tax and spend decisions required. A final thought is that Mr Sunak pledged pound.bn over five years to further education. Similar commitment to FE in Scotland must be a priority.Jeremy Peat is Visiting Professor at the University of Strathclyde

title: home-office-tell-83-year-old-chilean-dad-glasgow-go-home-nigeria
story: Myriam Giesen, from Riddrie, wants her dad Carlos Giesen Martinez to be allowed to stay inScotlandso she can look after him.Mr Giesen has strong links to Glasgow stretching back more than  years, having resided here from  to  as a political refugee during the General Augusto Pinochet regime.: More than three million EU citizens have applied to live in UK after BrexitWhile here he met and married his late we, Jean and adopted their daughter Myriam.Despite travelling from South America to Europe last year and spending most of the last five years between Scotland and Chile he has been told by the Home Office he should go back to Africa.The Glasgow Times reported how, ina written decision, the Home Office refused the application and told Mr Giesen ldquoYou should have prepared yourself for the possibility ofto Nigeria.The Home Office said it was a ldquomistake but Ms Giesen believes it to be a symptom of lack of attention being paid to decisions that seriously affect peoplersquos lives.Mr Geisenrsquos daughter and his lawyer believe the section citing Nigeria has been ldquocut and pasted from another refusal to a dferent applicant and is evidence the claim has not been given proper consideration.The Home Office also said Mr Giesen has been resident in Chile for  years, despite him having lived in the UK for  years.It also states, ldquoyou have indicated that you could be in danger of detention and torture due to the current state of affairs back in your country of origin, Chile.But no fear of torture or detention was raised and the only grounds for applying for leave to remain is on the basis of his relationship with his daughter and due to having no family or friends in Chile, except a grandson who is unable to commit to caring due to work.Carlos Giesen Martinez met daughter Myriams mother Jean after fleeing Chile for Scotland during the brutal Pinochet regime.The reason for the application is on compassionate grounds that he is not capable of caring for himself entirely in Chile.The application was made on the grounds of ldquoobstacles he would face reintegrating to le in Chile.It has been submitted that removing him would be a breach of his human rights and be disproportionate in the circumstances,resulting in unjustiably harsh consequences for both himself and his family.The application also stated Ms Giesen has sufficient income to support her father without recourse to public funds.Myriam said: ldquoI am the only person who can take care of him. There is no support for him in Chile.ldquoWe are not asking for any other benefits other than for him not to be deported.In the s after the Pinochet coup, Mr Giesen was detained for  months and tortured. He escaped to Argentina and then applied for refugee status to the UK.He was one of hundreds of thousands who were forced to flee persecution and torture, and one of around  Chileans who came to Scotland.He gained a masters degree in Literature at Glasgow University and ed to Chile in .Mr Giesen met Myriamrsquos mother, Jean, in  and they married in .Jean died in  and for the following three years he spend half the year in Chile and half in Scotland. Myriam lived in Chile.Following recent unrest in Chile, Myriam and her husband moved back to Scotland with her father in June . In December her father moved back to Chile but she said he was unable to care for himself properly.Mr Giesen came to Scotland in June last year and the family decided to apply for further leave to remain.The Home Office said they have no record of him entering the country then but Ms Giesen said his passport is stamped on leaving Chile and records will show he travelled to Scotland.She is a British citizen and had permanent residency in Chile when she lived there.The familyrsquos solicitor dealing with the case said it is ldquothe most staggering refusal he has known.He is concerned about the reference to Nigeria and the claim he has been resident in Chile for  years.Joseph Rasmussen, of Jones Whyte, said: ldquoMy concern is it is evident they have not considered the application in its entirety.ldquoHe was previously resident here for a considerable period of time.Mr Rasmussen said the refusal is dismissive of the human element to the caseHe added: ldquoThe mention of Nigeria reinforces the presumption that they havenrsquot considered it fully.The family are now preparing to appeal the decision later this monthThe Home Office said Mr Giesen does not meet the requirements to be allowed to stay.A Home Office spokeswoman said: ldquoAll immigration cases are carefully considered before a decision is made.ldquoMr Martinezrsquos application was refused as he was not able to demonstrate that he met the requirements for leave on the basis of his private le.The spokeswoman added: ldquoThe mention of Nigeria in Mr Martinezrsquos letter was a mistake and added he has the right to appeal against the refusal of his application.:Campaigner loses Home Office legal challenge over gender-neutral passportsIt is not the first time the Home Office has cited the wrong country of origin in immigration cases leading to suspicions that decisions are being lsquocopied and pastedrsquo from others.Last year a man who was caring for his terminally ill partner was told he faces deportation from the UK to Jamaica after the Home Office said in a refusal letter that he ldquofailed to demonstrate his le would be at risk in Iraq.The man, OrsquoNeil Wallfall had never been to Iraq but received the refusal letter suggesting his case had been confused with another.

title: coronavirus-nicola-sturgeon-says-sport-events-halted-delay-phase-begin
story: The First Minister said she believes the time has come to move into the delay phase for battling the virus, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson set to sign off on such plans during an emergency Government meeting on Thursday.Scottish Health Secretary Jeane Freeman will issue a statement on coronavirusto MSPs at Holyrood this afternoon.Ms Sturgeon warned it is highly likely "signicant numbers" of people will get the virus, with  cases confirmed in Scotland so far and the first case of community transmission north of the border reported on Wednesday.She said that while cancelling mass gatherings does not have a signicant impact on reducing the spread of the virus, such events tie up resources which could be used where.:Coronavirus LIVE: Donald Trump suspends all travel between US and EUShe told ITVs Good Morning Britain: "Mass gatherings, football matches for example, they need to be policed, they need to have emergency medical ambulance cover."We are going into a period where our emergency services, our NHS in particular, will be under signicant challenge and signicant pressure, we may see all of our workforces affected by high absentee rates because of sickness so theres a wider issue here about whether cancelling those kind of events is the right thing to do to reduce pressure on our front-line emergency workers."She added: "From a wider resilience point of view, then I think there is a big question mark over whether large-scale events like that, whether it is sensible to allow them to proceed at the moment."Were looking very carefully right now at whether large-scale events, whether it would be right and sensible given the situation we are facing right now to allow them to go ahead."Asked at what point the Scottish Government would consider closing schools, she said that could comeexperts advise it would be a beneficial thing to do.She said school closures are not currently being recommended but the situation is being kept under review, and decisions will be taken based on the best scientic advice.:Coronavirus in Scotland: Health secretary warns lives will change in disease battleMs Sturgeon said: "This is a serious situation. We cannot make this virus go away. It is highly likely now that signicant numbers of us are going to get this virus."The vast majority will have very mild illness and the clear focus right now is on doing everything we can to protect those who are more susceptible to serious illness, but we cannot make this go away, we need to focus on how we manage this outbreak, delay the spread and reduce the numbers infected at any one time."Nicola Sturgeon says the time has come to move from the contain phase to delay.Sturgeon will dial-in to a Cobra meeting with Boris Johnson today. pic oNRBwQrJScottish Secretary Alister Jack told BBC Radio Scotlands Good Morning Scotland programme there is "no doubt we are not going to be able to contain it for very much longer" and that efforts will now focus on delaying the spread of the virus to "put less pressure on the NHS".:UK expected to move into second phase of virus action planHe said: "The advice to date has been rather similar toyou have flu,you have flu symptoms dont go to work. The advice going forward will be more along the lines ofyou have a temperature with a cold - and I emphasise you have to have a temperature - not to go to work."If you are elderly please keep yourself as contained as you possibly can, oryou have underlying, pre-existing health conditions, particularly lung conditions, because what we are trying to do is take the pressure off the NHS and protect peoples lives."Mr Jack said he hopes the steps the UK is taking will prevent the need for "more extreme measures".

title: schools-colleges-ireland-close-two-weeks-stop-coronavirus
story: Taoiseach Leo Varadkar said the country ldquohad not faced a pandemic like this in living memory as he urged citizens to work from homethey can and limit social interaction.The announcement came a day after Ireland confirmed its first death from Covid-, the disease caused by the virus.The victim was an elderly woman who had been admitted to hospital in Dublin several days ago and had an underlying respiratory condition.Speaking in Washington DC, where he is meeting US President Donald Trump ahead of St Patrickrsquos Day, Mr Varadkar said closures would affect schools, nurseries, colleges and cultural institutions such as museums, and would remain in place until March .ldquoWhere possible teaching will be done online or remotely, said Mr Varadkar.Irelandrsquos intervention came at a time when the country had recorded only  confirmed cases of the virus, compared with hundreds in the UK.Nationwide school and university closures are also being rolled out in Denmark and the Czech Republic and are already in place in Italy, Japan, Iran, Iraq and Saudi Arabia.Mr Varadkar said Irelandrsquos way of le should change until the pandemic is brought under control.He said: ldquoOur advice is that all indoor mass gatherings of more than  people and outdoor mass gatherings of more than  people should be cancelled.ldquoYou should continue to go to workyou can but where possible you should work from home, and in order to reduce unnecessary fact-to-face interaction in the workplace, break times and working times should be staggered and meetings done remotely or by phone.ldquoPublic transport will continue to operate, the shops will remain open, and we have plans to ensure that supply chains will not be interrupted.ldquoRestaurants, cafes and other businesses can stay open but should look at ways they can implement public health advice on social distancing, and as a general rule outside of work people should seek to reduce social interactions as much as possible.It came as New York cancelled its St Patrickrsquos Day parade for the first time in more than  years.It was scheduled to take place on March . Mr Varadkar said he was acting on fresh advice from the countryrsquos National Public Health Emergency Team.ldquoWe have not witnessed a pandemic of this nature in living memory and this is uncharted territory for us, he said.ldquoWe said we would take the right actions at the right time and we have to move now to have the greatest impact.Irish health minister Simon Harris said the country had officially moved to the ldquodelay phase, which aims to reduce the peak impact of the virus and slow its spread.Meanwhile, Italy has stepped up its nationwide quarantine by closing all shops except pharmacies and food outlets until at least March .It had already closed schools, universities gyms, museums, nightclubs and ski resorts, but the restrictions were extended to bars, restaurants, hairdressers and non-essential company departments.Some criminal trials have also been halted.There were also reports that authorities in Italy could charge anyone with a cough, fever or other signs of possible coronavirus who refuses to self-isolate with attempted murder.Italy has been worst hit by the virus in Europe, with more than , cases and more than , deaths to date.Doctors have described running out of hospital beds and intensive care space as Italyrsquos health system was overwhelmed by an explosion in cases last month.One former NHS doctor now working in Italy warned that the situation there is like ldquobeing in a war.Professor Abu Hilal, who used to work at an NHS hospital in Southampton and is now chief of the department of surgery at Poliambulanza Institute Hospital Foundation, Brescia, tweeted that Covid ldquois serious.He added: ldquoPeople are dying, not only elderly.ldquoBeds are full. Governments must shut down everything, prepare beds, ventilators , antivirals, doctors and nurses. People should stay at home.It is unclear exactly why Italy has been so badly affected compared with other European nations.There are suggestions that aggressive testing for coronavirus in the wealthy Lombardy region has resulted in a much higher detection rate than other countries, as well as Italyrsquos unusually elderly population ndash due to long le expectancy ndash leaving it more exposed.There has also been criticism that initial cases were not isolated quickly enough, allowing the disease to spread unchecked and exacerbate the outbreak.The latest crackdown in Italy came as the US president announced a -day ban on flights from  European countries within the Schengen borderfree travel area.It does not affect the UK or Ireland.The announcement contributed to huge falls in stock markets around the world, with the FTSE  Index suffering its biggest one-day fall since  after plummeting . per cent.The Dow Jones led falls among US indexes, dropping more than %, while in Asia, Japanrsquos benchmark Nikkei  index closed .% down.Mr Trump called the ban the ldquomost aggressive and comprehensive effort to confront a foreign virus in modern history.He said one of the reasons the UK was not included in the travel ban was because of its borders.ldquoIt has got very strong borders and they are doing a very good job, he said.ldquoThey donrsquot have very much infection at this point and hopefully they will keep it that way.Mr Trump also claimed the US had ldquoa tremendous testing set-up, after a top health official said it was failing.Dr Anthony Fauci, from the US National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said the system ldquois not really geared to what we need right now.According to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention , the US has tested at least , people for the virus ndash although some tests in private hospitals and labs have not been reported.South Korea is testing nearly , people every day, while in the UK, more than , people have been tested. In Scotland, , tests have been carried out.
